name: Scratch - Waiting Room
description:
SCRATCH
(Mansfield General Hospital)
Waiting Room

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Hospitals in my experience are incredibly boring places, where huge amounts of waiting are done. What has become of this cavernous space, after being left for 21 years, makes it like an abstract puzzle maze, piecing the workings together and finding new rooms and objects that would have once been unexplorable as a member of the visiting public. What would have been a very dull visit is now like an adult playground fitted with its own ping-pong tables.

With no appointments, no patients to care for and no operations to carry out, it’s the polar opposite of its former self. From a place where sanitation and order was high on the agenda to a distorted carcass full of dirt and bacteria.

The last patient checked out of the hospital in 1992.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a
semi-matt finish. The paper is coated
with a slightly stippled finish and gives
a very natural photographic finish with
subtle colour.

50.8 x 25.4cm
20inch x 10inch
(White 15mm boarder top and bottom for easier framing)

Each is an Edition of 250, signed and numbered.

Prints sent by special delivery (UK) international first class overseas.
Rolled in tube (Please ask for framing options)

name: Piggy - Manor House
description:
PIGGY
(Manor House)
Living Room

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Left abandoned under Britain’s busiest flight path; This wreck of a house has a long history stemming back from the 14th Century. Left in a state of limbo, with all its furnishings more or less intact, the elements have slowly been reclaiming parts of the building. Room after room have collapsed and you wonder how such a grand home has been allowed to fall into this state of decay. With more reading than a mobile library, we fear much of it will be lost to yet more collapses. It demonstrates how nature left unhindered can pull something apart in a relatively short periods of neglect. More than any other place, you can feel the personal story of its final occupant, though the temptation to project one’s own experiences and ideas onto a supposed memory can distort and embellish the truth.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a
semi-matt finish. The paper is coated
with a slightly stippled finish and gives

name: Piggy - Barn
description:
PIGGY
(Beelitz Heilstätten)
Barn

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Our second hospital visit was very different, more of an abandoned town than one stand alone building. It consists of bakeries, barns and huge hospital wards built to treat tuberculosis at the end of the 19th century, most of it now left to rot. Some buildings have been saved and lived in, a trampoline sits outside one grand house, not 20 meters away from a barn housing a fascinating pile of clutter that seems to have been used as a playground of sorts. Room after room, building after building have been stripped and all that is left are empty shells, the hustle and bustle of it’s former years reduced to static sound.

The barn was certainly a surprise encounter where the former presence of an artist was still literally lingering in the air. Tin cups and discarded fragments of wood were suspended from the collapsed roof by wire and vibrant red strands of wool. This wool continued to form a web around the space, linking the chaotic, degradating sprawl of contents. A pig now acts as gallery attendant over this bizarre space.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a
semi-matt finish. The paper is coated
with a slightly stippled finish and gives
a very natural photographic finish with
subtle colour.

name: Suicidal Tendencies - Bakery
description:
SUICIDAL TENDANCIES
(Beelitz Heilstätten)
Bakery

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Our second hospital visit was very different, more of an abandoned town than one stand alone building. It consists of bakeries, barns and huge hospital wards built to treat tuberculosis at the end of the 19th century, most of it now left to rot. Some buildings have been saved and lived in, a trampoline sits outside one grand house, not 20 meters away from a barn housing a fascinating pile of clutter that seems to have been used as a playground of sorts. Room after room, building after building have been stripped and all that is left are empty shells, the hustle and bustle of it’s former years reduced to static sound.

Looking for the little details, we came across a bakery built at the
end of the 19th Century to cater for this hospital complex come
town. Complete with what is left of the Victorian equipment,
tiles reflect the green light of vegetation growing unattended in
the slowly encroaching forest. Cheeky palm trees stencilled
across the ceramics juxtapose against the collapsed floor in the
neighbouring room that remind you to watch your step.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.

name: Life Ain't Beautiful - Grand Staircase
description:
LIFE AIN’T BEAUTIFUL
(Beelitz Heilstätten)
Grand Staircase

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Our second hospital visit was very different, more of an abandoned town than one stand alone building. It consists of bakeries, barns and huge hospital wards built to treat tuberculosis at the end of the 19th century, most of it now left to rot. Some buildings have been saved and lived in, a trampoline sits outside one grand house, not 20 meters away from a barn housing a fascinating pile of clutter that seems to have been used as a playground of sorts. Room after room, building after building have been stripped and all that is left are empty shells, the hustle and bustle of it’s former years reduced to static sound.

The main staircase is a grand yet humorous relief to the repetitive wandering through empty corridors. This has changed hands and uses, from a 19th Century lung sanatorium, to a German First World War hospital treating a young Adolf Hitler among others. After the Second World War the Soviets set up here and you wonder who added the palm trees. It is almost waiting for a ‘wish you were here’ postcard to be made.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a
semi-matt finish. The paper is coated

name: Red Hood - Indoor forest
description:
RED HOOD 
(Wolfswinkel Papermill)
Indoor Forest

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Production ceased in here 1994;
Once a thriving production line for the German Reich’s banknotes and treasury papers, not much is now left of the water powered paper mill. Its empty factory floor has on one end been turned into a makeshift caravan-building workshop, the rest into a playground for artists. Among the buildings that skirt the canal is an indoor forest and pond. A lack of roof has created has created its own eco system that softens what once would have been a warehouse.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a

name: No More Chess - Burnt out Corridor
description:
NO MORE CHESS
(Iraqi Embassy)
Burnt out Corridor 

Original photo print for Conquer Gear © by Anthony Lycett.
(Sold without water mark shown in picture)

Abandoned 1991
There is something to be said for not publicising abandoned spaces far and wide; it attracts more people on a weekend than an art gallery. The first time we went here on a cold January weekday the only people around were office workers staring from desktops of neighbouring offices, as we went around and leafed through Saddam Hussein’s old pamphlets. It felt eerie and disconnected from its surroundings that day. Now it seems like the number one weekend destination for
couples on a date, as we found out to our surprise when we walked in on a man photographing his naked girlfriend in one of the bathrooms. After readjusting to this idea of people on a very strange day out, it dawned on us that this of all places, where the ‘Memories’ project was first formed in our minds, has become an unofficial gallery space. Leaving Conquer prints here seemed incredibly natural, as many groups traipsed past us as we took photos they didn’t seem perturbed in the slightest.

Part of the "memories collection" each photo features an Illustration by Tomoya Hiramatsu

Photo Print, on C-Type Matt Fujifilm.
Fuji Crystal Archive paper with a
semi-matt finish. The paper is coated

name: Elephant Athletic Grey Cardigan
description:
Elephant - The beauty of an elephant is not diminished by our use of their imagery , but we include the weight of the world in our picture to remind ourselves the reality is not as rosy as we would wish. Animals have always been used for our own purposes, even if it is to sell nature documentaries or cushion covers.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.
 
Tri-Blend (50% Polyester / 25% Cotton / 25% Rayon) construction
Polyester retains shape and elasticity; Cotton lends both comfort and durability; addition of Rayon makes for a unique texture and drapes against the body for a slimming look

This 6 button Cardigan is a unisex garment, women may wish to order one size smaller.

Crow	 - Crows are commonly known as the 'bird of death', so to call it a murder of crows makes sense. They are known to scavenge corpses and when they fly over you, it’s supposedly a bad omen. But we have never cared too much for superstition.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

WOMEN'S CURVED HEM JERSEY VEST
100% Tencel Lyocell Fine Jersey 120g
(Made from sustainable sourced Eucalyptus tree Pulp)	

The material is well known for its outstanding physical characteristics - silky softness and luxurious drape. It is perfectly smooth, with depth of colour, excellent moisture absorbency, and is naturally hygienic as it inhibits the growth of bacteria. 
This tank top has a flattering curved hem that flows with your shape. 

Check the sizing chart for dimensions.	

Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation promoting Ethical Trade and Justice for workers.

name: Finger Crossed  black Tank Top
description:
Fingers Crossed - Drawn whilst waiting for a visa that never came through.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear © by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

Women’s Tank Top
100% Cotton, 115g.	Super lightweight. 

Perfect for summer, This female shape slightly widens at the base so is not as form fitting around the hips as some of our more tailored cuts.
Still a good fit for bust and is a flattering shape.  

Check the sizing chart for dimensions.	

Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation, promoting Ethical Trade and Justice for workers.

name: Apple Grey Crop Top (Tencel)
description:
Vaj-apple - Our apple reflects our quest for knowledge and with it the awareness of one’s own self. Why are we ashamed of our forms as nature intended? Adam and Eve, free from the confines of knowledge were quite happy running naked in the garden.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

WOMEN'S CROP TOP T-SHIRT
100% Tencel Lyocell Fine Jersey 120g
(Made from sustainable sourced Eucalyptus tree Pulp)

The material is well known for its outstanding physical characteristics - silky softness and luxurious drape. It is perfectly smooth, with depth of colour, excellent moisture absorbency, and is naturally hygienic as it inhibits the growth of bacteria. 
Due to the nature of the fabric being super lightweight, this garment hangs loose and has a natural flow to it. 

Check the sizing chart for dimensions.	

Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation, promoting Ethical Trade and Justice for workers.

name: Red Hood Coral Rolled Sleeve-T (Organic)
description:
Red Hood - Our Red Riding Hood doesn’t do Al Fresco. Happily ever after didn’t fit with our Grimm tale.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

WOMEN’S ROLLED-UP SLEEVE T-SHIRT
100% Organic Cotton Jersey 155 g/m2

Our roll-sleeve is a classic T. Check the sizing chart for dimensions.

100% Organic Product in accordance with the Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS). 
Certified by the Control Union, Carbon Trust and Soil Association with a 90% reduced Carbon Footprint.
Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation.

name: Owl, Melange grey V-Neck Tunic
description:

womens plunge V-neck Extra fine jursey tunic
100% Combed Cotton Sheer Jersey 105g / 3.15oz.

This is supposed to be worn over another garment and it runs long, well past the waist. Best layered over tank tops or similar and you can combine many colours under this granite like melange grey!
 
Check the sizing chart for dimensions.

Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation, promoting Ethical Trade and Justice for workers

name: Laughter White 3/4 Sleeve Raglan T-shirt (Tencel)
description:
Laughter - It’s astounding how the look of laughter and pain can be so similar. The kanji text here reads laughter under the image.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

WOMEN'S 3/4 SLEEVE RAGLAN T-SHIRT
100% Tencel Lyocell Fine Jersey 120g
(Made from sustainable sourced Eucalyptus tree Pulp)	

The material is well known for its outstanding physical characteristics - silky softness and luxurious drape. It is perfectly smooth, with depth of colour, excellent moisture absorbency, and is naturally hygienic as it inhibits the growth of bacteria. 
This is a traditional ¾ length raglan sleeve.
 
Check the sizing chart for dimensions.  	

Audited by the Fair Wear Foundation, promoting Ethical Trade and Justice for workers.

name: Laughter Tri-Evergreen Batwing Pullover
description:
Laughter - It’s astounding how the look of laughter and pain can be so similar. The kanji text here reads laughter under the image.

Original illustration for Conquer Gear ® by Tomoya Hiramatsu.

Women’s Pullover;
Tri-Blend 125g 3.7oz. (50% Polyester / 25% Cotton / 25% Rayon) construction
Polyester retains shape and elasticity; Cotton lends both comfort and durability; addition of Rayon makes for a unique texture and drapes against the body for a slimming look

Our pullover features a batwing sleeve with elasticated cuffs so you can achieve an easy ¾ sleeve. 

Check the sizing chart for dimensions.	

Garment supplied by American Apparel, they apply a vertical integration strategy to their manufacture process. All our garments coming from AA are knit, dyed, cut, sewn and packed under the same roof in downtown L.A. Purpose built factory minimises waste and delivers fair wages and treatment for all workers in accordance of US labour/employment laws.
